etymologies: 1930s: from modern Latin, from Greek tritos ‘third’

definitions: a radioactive isotope of hydrogen with a mass approximately three times that of the common protium isotope.

notes.text: Discovered in 1934, tritium has two neutrons as well as a proton in the nucleus. It occurs in minute traces in nature and can be made artificially from lithium or deuterium in nuclear reactors; it is used as a fuel in thermonuclear bombs

shortDefinitions: radioactive isotope of hydrogen with mass approximately three times that of usual isotope
